title: GitHub - cavi-au/Consent-O-Matic: Browser extension that automatically fills out cookie popups based on your preferences

last_post.content:
Consent-O-Matic is a browser extension that auto-responds to all the #GDPR and similar consent popups with optimal user preferences.

Unlike the extension "I don't care about cookies" which just accepts all cookies, Consent-O-Matic clicks the prompts on your behalf to reject most of the cookies. You can also choose what to accept/reject in the preferences.

Available for Firefox, Chrome and others.

I've been using this on Firefox :firefox: for quite sometime now and it works great!

Their Github page has links to official extension stores: https://github.com/cavi-au/Consent-O-Matic#introduction

#AMO link: https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/addon/consent-o-matic/

#privacy #webextensions #addons #addon #extension #chrome #firefox #safari

title: What Happened When DataCamp Tried To Cover Up Its CEO’s Sexual Misconduct

last_post.content: Five years later, I still occasionally get pokes on LinkedIn saying, "Hey, you used to work at DataCamp, what can you tell me about them?" My response is, "Their CEO committed sexual assault, they tried to bury the story, he finally stepped aside after an outcry but returned while everyone was distracted by COVID." See https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/daveyalba/datacamp-sexual-harassment-metoo-tech-startup for @daveyalba's excellent summary from 2019 and https://third-bit.com/2019/04/15/an-exchange-with-datacamp/ for a personal addendum.

Five years later, I still occasionally get pokes on LinkedIn saying, "Hey, you used to work at DataCamp, what can you tell me about them?" My response is, "Their CEO committed sexual assault, they tried to bury the story, he finally stepped aside after an outcry but returned while everyone was distracted by COVID." title: Hashtags are everything on Mastodon — why not give them a home?

last_post.content: #Hashtags are everything on #Mastodon why not give them a home? Mastodon lets you #search for hashtags or keep columns open to track them. In addition to basic topic headings like #politics #music, people write posts w tags like #LawFedi or #lawstodon for legal posts, #intro for people joining the service. Mastodon should have a #WordPress-style or #Friendica-style method for listing #tags separately from content of the post with a separate character limit for the tags. https://www.theverge.com/23673125/mastodon-separate-tags-hashtag-navigation-accessibility

The third report on the R-spatial evolution project has been published. It links back to earlier blogs and presentations, and focusses on work that maintainers of R packages and workflows using rgdal, rgeos and maptools need to put in train now. The first changes will occur in June 2023, and the retiring packages will be archived during October 2023. If you are giving a workshop or tutorial during the Northern hemisphere summer, aim for June. #rspatial @rsbivand

https://r-spatial.org/r/2023/04/10/evolution3.html

title: Do you actually need a vector database? | Ethan Rosenthal

last_post.content:
New blog post: Do you actually need a vector database?
https://www.ethanrosenthal.com/2023/04/10/nn-vs-ann/

To go along with the blog post, I made a small repo to benchmark using a "vector DB" (aka approximate nearest neighbors) with "brute-force" nearest neighbors https://github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-vs-ann

The main takeaway is that the brute-force method takes ~50 milliseconds / 1 million embeddings on my computer, so hopefully those numbers can help you to make a decision on whether you need a vector DB!

New blog post: Do you actually need a vector database?
https://www.ethanrosenthal.com/2023/04/10/nn-vs-ann/

To go along with the blog post, I made a small repo to benchmark using a "vector DB" (aka approximate nearest neighbors) with "brute-force" nearest neighbors https://github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-vs-ann

The main takeaway is that the brute-force method takes ~50 milliseconds / 1 million embeddings on my computer, so hopefully those numbers can help you to make a decision on whether you need a vector DB!

Basically:

🔹 AI doesn't reliably give useful results, but even if it did
🔹 AI rampantly perpetuates existing harms, but even if it didn't
🔹 AI proponents are not being honest or acting in good faith, but even if they were
🔹 People don't understand the limits of LLMs or how they work, but even if they did
🔹 AI cannot maintain a complex system because it's fundamentally a task of understanding the system, but even if it could

Humans still need opportunity to learn how to make sense of those systems, and we do that by making them. Giving all the work that's most conducive to learning to a computer is selling out our futures. Even if there was some present benefit, which I'm not convinced there is.

https://jenniferplusplus.com/losing-the-imitation-game/

From the incredible @adamconover and @pluralistic

Los Angeles is suing a journalist and a police watchdog group in an attempt to claw back public records that it had released to them after police invented a new definition of the word "undercover": https://theintercept.com/2023/04/11/los-angeles-lawsuit-lapd-headshots/

In short: LA handed over a dataset of LAPD headshots to a journalist as part of a Public Records settlement. Stop LAPD Spying Coalition launched a searchable database of LAPD cops using the data at https://watchthewatchers.net/. For example, here's Police Chief Moore.

After the LAPD police union noticed, they flipped their shit. Now, they've convinced the city of LA to sue Ben Camacho, the journalist, and the Stop LAPD Spying Coalition, trying to claw back the public records. But it's doomed to fail. The data is all over the internet, including published by DDoSecrets: https://ddosecrets.substack.com/p/release-lapd-headshots-269-mb

Several First Amendment experts have denounced the lawsuit as legally meritless. "Once the government gives you information in good faith, you have the right to publish it under the First Amendment. This is not even a close case." -David Loy, legal director of the First Amendment Coalition https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2023-04-06/la-officials-sue-journalist-activist-group-after-accidentally-releasing

title: Did Lichtenstein create art or copy it? A new film stokes the controversy.

EUBUCCO is a “database of individual building footprints for 200+ million buildings across the 27 European Union countries and Switzerland”: https://eubucco.com/

The database also contains "three main attributes – building type, height and construction year – included for respectively 45%, 74%, 24% of the buildings."

More details in today's edition of Data Is Plural: https://www.data-is-plural.com/archive/2023-04-05-edition/

title: Twitter takes down post on Home Minister globally

last_post.content:
RT @sarahemclaugh
It looks like Twitter is *globally* withholding a tweet in response to a legal demand in India. This is a disaster for free speech online. Indian law dictating social media speech rules globally—a worst case scenario for free speech and content moderation. https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/twitter-takes-down-post-on-home-minister-globally/article66711854.ece

This is a good time to set up a monthly contribution to help offset the costs of your Mastodon instance. (Yes, your use of this is incurring costs that are being paid by someone else. There are no banks, billionaires, and advertisers to eat the cost of hosting.)

If you’re here on vis.social, see ways to contribute: https://vis.social/about

❤️

I made @nycviewsbot a few years ago for a tutorial I wrote for https://botwiki.org to show how to make a bot that posts random webcam pictures from around a city.

I cringe every time I see this bot post yet another traffic jam.

I finally got around to manually reviewing all NYC webcams and the result is a much better and a more focused celebration of what is still one of the greatest cities.

Hope you'll enjoy this updated version!

#bots #nyc #webcam

last_post.content:
JWST has allowed astronomers to discover the four oldest galaxies ever detected. This is just a delightful science story.

https://phys.org/news/2023-04-webb-telescope-oldest-galaxies.html

ICYMI: A dataset of 1,000 Photos of Dolphin Fins collected by NOAA researchers. Scars, scratches and wounds abound in these photos as encounters with unknown creatures and boat propellers leave their marks, imprinting a story of close escapes and cheating death. The combination of marks are unique enough to identify individuals for tracking them over time and to study their social networks. #🐬 https://www.beautifulpublicdata.com/1000-photos-of-dolphin-fins/ #wildlife #nature #dolphins #marinemammals #noaa #ocean

I recently wrote an intro vignette for the R implementation of `polars`. https://rpolars.github.io/articles/rpolars.html

If you haven't heard of it yet: `polars` is a new-ish data wrangling library, originally written in Rust, but with bindings to several other languages (most notably Python but now R and NodeJS).

Lots to like and very fast.

title: ‘Free Speech’ Twitter Is Now Globally Blocking Posts Critical Of The Modi Government

last_post.content:
Globally restricting speech based on local legal demands (in this case, from India) is exactly as terrifying as @mmasnick makes it sound in this post. https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/11/free-speech-twitter-is-now-globally-blocking-posts-critical-of-the-modi-government/

This was EXCEEDINGLY rare in the Twitter 1.0 days — I can think of a vanishingly small number of examples, all of which involved extensive litigation and pushback to avoid having to comply.

A dark day for free speech indeed.

O'Reilly Radar gave the Fediverse a shout-out!

They note that the Fediverse is on pace to match Twitter's scale.

But they also question whether the industry pundits will ever take the Fediverse seriously since it lacks billionaire or VC funding.

Fine by me.

Let the pundits write their long thinkpieces on NFTs and AI and all the other bullshit that powers tech hype cycles.

As for me, I'm here for actual and tangible technological change.

This example of a digital relict of a largely obsolete technology (seeing a floppy disk and thinking "save icon") made me remember seeing a talk from Amelia Acker a number of years ago about work on youth data literacy. Something that stuck out at me was the finding that young people who grow up using phones and tablets rather than computers might have no understanding of how a file system works. Some of those findings discussed here: https://www.yalsa.ala.org/jrlya/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Bowler-Acker-Chi_PerspectivesOnYouthDataLiteracy_FINAL.pdf

Terra Nil might be called a reverse citybuilder, but it's actually a boardgame that doesn't realise it's a boardgame.

It looks great! But has a *lot* of game design problems that make it way more confusing and annoying than it needed to be. And some of the things it makes you do are completely opposite to its theme of restoring environments!

https://adrianhon.substack.com/p/terra-nil
